coredata.dc:title: Robust coal matrix intensifies electron/substrate interaction of nickel-nitrogen (Ni-N) active sites for efficient CO2 electroreduction at industrial current density
coredata.dc:creator: Liu, Weiqi
Wei, Shilin
Bai, Peiyao
Yang, Chuangchuang
Xu, Lang
coredata.dc:description: Carbon encapsulating metal composites have been widely employed in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Though these catalysts possess relatively high selectivity towards CO, their current densities are usually low, which hardly satisfy industrial requirements. Achieving industrial current densities requires robust catalyst supports alongside efficient electron/substrate interaction at catalytically active sites. Herein, we select anthracite coal with a naturally robust architecture as the catalyst support, whose internal dense framework favours electron transport. The controllable activation method is used to form numerous micropores at the surface of coal particles without destroying the internal structures. The spatial confinement growth effect of micropores within the coal matrix contributes to the fixation of nickel-nitrogen (Ni-N) active sites within the micropores to prevent excessive agglomeration of metallic atoms, therefore enhancing the catalyst utilization. Furthermore, confinement space provided by plentiful micropores favours the adsorption of CO2, ensuring the instantaneous supply of a sufficient concentration of the substrate molecules to adjacent active sites firmly anchored in the micropores. Accordingly, the robust coal matrix can not only promote electrons from the inside to surface catalytic centres but also capture CO2 from the outside to active sites, thus intensifying the electron/substrate interaction of Ni-N active sites. In a flow cell, the coal-matrix electrocatalyst co-doped with nickel and nitrogen exhibits an industry-level current density of 223 mA cm–2, a high faradaic efficiency of 97% for CO production and a long-term stability of continuously working for as long as 120 h. Consequently, this work advances the understanding of catalyst supports in intensifying the electron/substrate interaction of active sites and hence provides new insight into the optimization of electrocatalytic performance of earth-abundant transition metals through the incorporation into the robust coal matrix.

head.ce:title: Robust coal matrix intensifies electron/substrate interaction of nickel-nitrogen (Ni-N) active sites for efficient CO2 electroreduction at industrial current density

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: MOE Key Laboratory of Coal Processing and Efficient Utilization, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, China University of Mining and Technology, 1 Daxue Road, Xuzhou, Jiangsu 221116, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Carbon encapsulating metal composites have been widely employed in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Though these catalysts possess relatively high selectivity towards CO, their current densities are usually low, which hardly satisfy industrial requirements. Achieving industrial current densities requires robust catalyst supports alongside efficient electron/substrate interaction at catalytically active sites. Herein, we select anthracite coal with a naturally robust architecture as the catalyst support, whose internal dense framework favours electron transport. The controllable activation method is used to form numerous micropores at the surface of coal particles without destroying the internal structures. The spatial confinement growth effect of micropores within the coal matrix contributes to the fixation of nickel-nitrogen (Ni-N) active sites within the micropores to prevent excessive agglomeration of metallic atoms, therefore enhancing the catalyst utilization. Furthermore, confinement space provided by plentiful micropores favours the adsorption of CO2, ensuring the instantaneous supply of a sufficient concentration of the substrate molecules to adjacent active sites firmly anchored in the micropores. Accordingly, the robust coal matrix can not only promote electrons from the inside to surface catalytic centres but also capture CO2 from the outside to active sites, thus intensifying the electron/substrate interaction of Ni-N active sites. In a flow cell, the coal-matrix electrocatalyst co-doped with nickel and nitrogen exhibits an industry-level current density of 223 mA cm–2, a high faradaic efficiency of 97% for CO production and a long-term stability of continuously working for as long as 120 h. Consequently, this work advances the understanding of catalyst supports in intensifying the electron/substrate interaction of active sites and hence provides new insight into the optimization of electrocatalytic performance of earth-abundant transition metals through the incorporation into the robust coal matrix.

ce:section.ce:para: Consumption of fossil fuels has caused the continued growth of atmospheric CO2, and the resulting climate change has focused public attention on the development of renewable energy [1]. It is worth noting that production costs of many renewable energy technologies have diminished steadily [2]. The intermittent characteristic of renewable energy offers important opportunities for electrochemical energy storage and conversion [3]. Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can not only utilize clean electricity generated by renewable energy to transform electrical energy into chemical energy but also contribute to the close of anthropogenic chemical carbon cycle [4]. CO2 can be electrochemically converted into a variety of products [5–7]. Among them, CO that is obtained by undergoing the two-electron CO2RR process has a great advantage in terms of conversion kinetics compared with other reduction products [8]. Furthermore, CO is a fundamental feedstock for syntheses of high value-added chemicals through the Fischer-Tropsch process and an efficient reductant for metallurgical industry, demonstrating its important role in industrial production [9].

Research on the CO2 electroreduction to CO can be traced back to 1985, when Hori investigated a series of metals and found that Au as well as Ag had the relatively high selectivity towards CO [10]. Considerable research effort has been applied to improving electrocatalytic activity by engineering electronic and/or geometric structures of Au- or Ag-based catalysts [11,12]. Peng et al., for example, synthesized preferentially oriented nanoparticles of metallic Ag (PON-Ag) by adjusting cell voltages precisely, and the deliberately exposed (110) and (100) crystal surfaces enabled PON-Ag to have higher selectivity to CO than polycrystalline Ag [13]. Lu et al. used an electrochemical dealloying method for the preparation of nanoporous Au, which exhibited a high faradaic efficiency of 98% for CO formation with an overpotential of 390 mV [14]. Despite the good catalytic performance of these electrocatalysts, high prices and limited supplies of precious metals indeed restrict their large-scale production. As viable alternatives, nonprecious metals are being studied for the CO2 electroreduction to CO [15,16]. On the other hand, many of nonprecious metals provide the bias to favour the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) relative to the CO2RR [17]. Since carbonaceous materials possess essential features, such as adjustable pore structures and high corrosion resistance, the strategy for encapsulating metal active centres within carbon supports has become a favourable approach to improving the product selectivity and preventing the leaching of metal components. For instance, Li et al. obtained cobalt sites fixed on hollow nitrogen-doped porous carbon spheres by a template method [18]; Gu et al. prepared nickel single atoms based on nitrogen-doped carbon supports through a two-step process: a porous zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) was first synthesized as a carbon precursor and nickel active sites were then anchored onto carbon supports derived from the ZIF by a high-temperature calcination [19]. Though these catalysts have comparable selectivity towards CO with precious-metal catalysts, their current densities are often low (less than 50 mA cm–2). Accordingly, it is necessary to prepare efficient electrocatalysts able to achieve both high selectivity (>90%) and high current density (>100 mA cm–2), meeting requirements of industrial production [20].

To improve the electrocatalytic performance, intense efforts have been made to increase metal loading [21,22]. However, the high loading is prone to excessive agglomeration of metals in the processes of high-temperature treatments or high-current measurements, resulting in the performance degradation [19]. Modifying metals themselves is being under intense investigation whereas roles that catalyst supports play in the performance of reaction sites should not be underestimated. Carbon supports with tailored structures are able to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of metal-based catalysts while protecting them during the electrolysis [23,24]. Among a large array of carbon-based materials, medium/high-rank coals as exemplified by anthracite have naturally robust architectures, which can acquire both high corrosion resistance and high mechanical strength. In our previous work, we found that nitrogen atoms confined in the micropores of anthracite-based metal-free material could improve the electrocatalytic CO2RR activity significantly [25]. Consequently, a robust and porous coal matrix should be able to enhance catalytic performance of nonprecious metals. Additionally, it is worth noting that worldwide reserves of anthracite make possible the mass production [26]. To the best of our knowledge, using the coal matrix to enhance nonprecious metal-based, electrocatalytic CO2RR performance has yet to be systematically studied.

In this work, we make nickel and nitrogen co-doped carbon composites based on the robust structure of anthracite coal. The chemical activation processing produces numerous micropores at the surface of coal particles. And the increase in surface roughness provides sufficient attachment points for the subsequent self-assembly of nickel and organic ligands. After the calcination step, nickel is firmly fixed into the micropore structure of coal particles. The confined growth effect of micropores contributes to the uniform distribution of nickel in the coal matrix, thus increasing the catalyst utilization. Moreover, the coal matrix enhances the electronic conductivity and enriches the reaction substrate, hence intensifying the electron/substrate interaction over active sites. Benefiting from the advantages of coal matrix, the as-obtained electrocatalyst shows a high faradaic efficiency of 98% for the CO2 electroreduction to CO at a potential of −0.8 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) in an H-shaped electrolytic cell. Furthermore, an industrial current density (223 mA cm–2), a high faradaic efficiency (97%) and a long-term stability of continuously working for as long as 120 h are achieved in a flow cell, demonstrating the great significance of coal matrix in enhancing electrocatalytic CO2RR performance. Our results thereby provide new insight into electrocatalytic performance optimization of metal-based catalysts by tailoring the pore structure of carbon supports.

10 g of raw anthracite coal were ground in a CSXQM-1 ball-milling apparatus operating at 400 rpm for two hours. Then, 3 g of pulverized coal were successively treated with 3 M KOH, 1 M HCl and ultrapure water at 60 ºC for two hours to remove impurities in the coal. The purified raw anthracite coal was denoted PRAC. Subsequently, 0.3 g of PRAC and 0.9 g of KOH were added in 5 mL ethanol and 5 mL ultrapure water, and the resulting mixture was heated at 80 ºC with vigorous stirring and placed in a vacuum oven at 80 ºC overnight for drying. The solid was calcinated at 800 ºC for two hours in a N2 flow of 80 mL min–1 at 3 ºC min–1. The as-obtained powder was washed with 1 M HCl at 60 ºC under stirring for two hours and subsequently with ultrapure water until neutral pH was reached. Then the porous coal (referred to as PC) was desiccated at 80 ºC overnight. Next, 0.15 g of PC and 0.225 g of Ni(NO3)2•6 H2O were uniformly dispersed into 2 mL ethanol and 10 mL ultrapure water by an ultrasonic treatment for half an hour, and the resulting mixture was quickly poured into 20 mL aqueous solution composed of 2-methylimizole (2-MeIM, 2.75 g). After being stirred for six hours, the mixture was separated using a centrifuge and washed with ultrapure water for three times. The resulting sample was denoted C@NNi. Later, C@NNi was moved to a tube furnace and calcinated at a certain temperature (600, 700 and 800 ºC) for two hours in a constant flow of N2 (80 mL min–1) at 3 ºC min–1. Subsequently, the samples were immersed in 1 M HCl for two hours at 60 ºC to remove unstable metal particles, followed by being filtered and dried at 80 ºC overnight. The as-prepared catalysts calcinated at 600, 700 and 800 ºC were referred to as CNNi-600, CNNi-700 and CNNi-800, respectively.

To study the impact of coal matrix, a reference sample C-N-Ni-700 (without the coal matrix) was prepared by the same method as CNNi-700, except that PC was not used in the preparation of C-N-Ni-700. Additionally, to evaluate whether the pore structure of coal matrix can withstand the high temperature, PC was directly calcined at 700 ºC under the same condition as CNNi-700 except that Ni(NO3)2•6H2O and 2-MeIM were not employed, and the synthesized sample was denoted PC-700.

N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms collected at 77 K and CO2 adsorption isotherms measured at 298.15 K were performed by Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ apparatus, and evaluations of pore width distributions were carried out by the quenched solid density functional theory (QSDFT) model. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were taken using FEI TF30 and ZEISS GeminiSEM 300, respectively. Raman spectra were recorded using Bruker Senterra confocal Raman spectrometer excited by a laser beam of 532 nm. Thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) measurements were taken by NETZSCH STA 449C under N2 atmosphere. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were made by Bruker D8 advance, operating with the Cu-Kα radiation (λ: 1.5406 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were taken by Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi using Al Kα X-ray (1489.6 eV). The binding energy scale was corrected based on the C 1s peak (284.8 eV). Nickel contents were measured by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Thermo iCAP Qc). In situ attenuated total reflectance-surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) data were collected using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector.

For the preparation of cathodes, 8 mg of a certain sample were added to 980 μL isopropanol and 20 μL 5% Nafion solution. The homogeneous mixture obtained by a one-hour ultrasonic treatment was evenly dropped on carbon paper (0.5 cm2, working electrode used in an H-shaped cell) or gas diffusion layer (1.44 cm2, working electrode used in a flow cell), and the loading of each sample for each test is 0.8 mg cm–2. The reference and counter electrodes were Ag/AgCl (in 3.5 M KCl) and Pt foil, respectively. All applied potentials were rescaled to the RHE according to E (RHE) = E (Ag/AgCl) + 0.0592 × pH + 0.1989 V.

A gas-tight H-shaped electrochemical cell was used to assess the electrocatalytic activities of the samples. In the H-shaped cell, the two compartments were separated by a Nafion 115 membrane, using 40 mL 0.5 M KHCO3 as an electrolyte in each compartment. Prior to each measurement, the cathode compartment was ventilated with CO2 for half an hour, and CO2 was constantly supplied to the cathode compartment at 10 mL min–1 during the electrocatalytic CO2RR measurements. Linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) experiments were conducted at 5 mV s–1. Electrolytic experiments were carried out between –0.5 and −1.2 V, and the experiments were repeated 3 times at each potential. Electrochemical surface area (ECSA) values were measured based on capacitive currents together with double-layer capacitances (C dl) from cyclic voltammograms (CV). The CV tests were conducted at a series of scan rates (i.e., 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 mV s–1) in 0.5 ~ 0.7 V. The slope value obtained by the curve of Δj (j a-j c) at 0.6 V with respect to the scan rate was twice C dl [27]. With an AC voltage amplitude of 5 mV, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments were undertaken in the range from 10–2 to 105 Hz.

A custom-made flow cell made of plexiglass was also employed. The sealed flow cell consisted of a gas-phase flow chamber and two liquid-phase flow chambers, in which the anode and cathode chambers were separated by a Sustainion X37–50 grade 60 membrane and the CO2 gas was isolated from the catholyte by a gas diffusion electrode (GDE). The electrolytes used in the anode and cathode chambers were both 1 M KOH, which were circulated at 40 mL min–1 by two peristaltic pumps. Meanwhile, CO2 was continuously introduced into the electrolytic cell at 60 mL min–1.

An on-line gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890B) was linked to the cathode compartment of the H-shaped cell or the cathode chamber of the flow cell for detection of gas-phase products obtained from the CO2RR. Possible liquid products were detected by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) apparatus (Bruker AVANCE NEO). Faradaic efficiency (FE) values of reduction products were obtained based on the equation:
FE =
znF
Q
× 100 %
where F is the Faraday constant (96485 C mol–1); n is moles of a product; z is number of electrons transferred to a product (for CO or H2, z = 2); Q is the total number of electrons supplied to the electrochemical system.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparations of Ni,N-codoped carbon composites: coal-matrix vs. coal-free
ce:section.ce:para: The synthetic process is described schematically in Fig. 1(a). As the starting material, the PRAC particles having a diameter of several microns are obtained by the ball-milling processing (Fig. S1a,b). From a consideration of the smooth surface of these particles, it is necessary to employ the activation method to create plentiful pores at the surface of coal particles to improve catalytic activity [28,29]. As shown in Fig. S1c,d, the PC particles are rich in bumps and voids able to provide large specific surface area for attachment of metal active centres. This can be identified by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms depicted in Fig. S2a. The adsorption-desorption isotherm of PC exhibits the typical Type I isotherm, showing the formation of abundant micropores within the coal matrix of PC [30,31]. After the self-assembly of PC, 2-MeIM and the nickel salt at room temperature, the obtained C@NNi presents the negligible nitrogen uptake (Fig. S2a), indicating the compact texture of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite composed of Ni ions and 2-MeIM. The specific surface area decreases dramatically from 2059.2 m2 g–1 for PC to merely 23.4 m2 g–1 for C@NNi (Table S1), suggesting that the micropore structure of PC particles is blocked by the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite.

After the calcination processing, CNNi-600, CNNi-700 and CNNi-800 all display the typical Type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 1b), in which the rapid elevations of nitrogen adsorption capacities at P/P 0 < 0.1 indicate the abundance of micropores attributed to the re-exposed micropore structure of coal matrix after the calcination and the acidic leaching. Specifically, as the temperature rises from 600 to 700 ºC, the pore volumes and surface areas of the corresponding samples increase significantly (Table S1), which indicates that the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite of C@NNi gradually decomposes. However, further raising the temperature to 800 ºC results in the marked decrease in both pore volume and surface area, which demonstrates that the pore shrinkage of coal matrix at the excessively high temperature leads to the disappearance of numerous micropores [25]. Furthermore, the presence of hysteresis loops implies the formation of mesopores for the CNNi-series samples (Fig. 1b) [30].

As presented in Fig. 1(c) and Table S1, a substantial number of micropores in the coal matrices of CNNi-600, CNNi-700 and CNNi-800 are largely restored, but not completely, compared with their common precursor PC, showing that the metal components produced by the thermal decomposition of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite indeed enter into the micropore structure of coal matrix and occupy part of cavities. On the other hand, almost no mesopores are present in PC (S mic /S BET = 0.96), so the mesopores of the CNNi-series samples should originate from the decomposition of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite rather than PC itself, which can be confirmed by the textural parameters of non-coal C-N-Ni-700. Without any coal matrix, C-N-Ni-700 that exhibits the greater hysteresis loop (Fig. 1b) indeed possesses predominantly mesopores (S meso /S BET = 0.93) and much more mesopores than the CNNi-series samples, but very few micropores (Table S1 and Fig. 1c). It can be therefore inferred from the physisorption data that the mesopores of the CNNi-series samples are derived from the coal-free 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite whereas the micropores come from the coal-matrix PC.

Benefiting from the confinement space provided by plentiful micropores in the coal matrix, the CO2 adsorption capacity of CNNi-700 reaches as high as 56.3 cm3 g–1 (Fig. 1d), which can supply the sufficient reaction substrate to metal active sites anchored in the pores and thus promote the CO2 electroreduction [32]. On the contrary, the CO2 adsorption capacity of C-N-Ni-700 is only 16.2 cm3 g–1 (Fig. 1d) due to the lack of substrate enrichment provided by the coal matrix, which is therefore unfavourable for the improvement of its electrocatalytic performance. Moreover, PC-700 synthesized by the direct calcination of PC with an inert atmosphere of N2 shows the similar specific surface area and pore structure to PC (Fig. S2a,b and Table S1), suggesting the robust pore structure of coal matrix as well as the negligible impact of calcination temperature on the coal matrix.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Changing and unchanging properties of Ni,N-codoped carbon composites with coal matrix
ce:section.ce:para: In order to confirm whether nickel is anchored and how it is distributed within the coal matrix, the SEM and TEM measurements have been taken to investigate a range of morphologies and surface properties of the samples. As presented in Fig. S3a,c,e, the degree of surface roughness of CNNi-600, CNNi-700 and CNNi-800 is steadily reduced as the calcination temperature is raised from 600 to 800 ºC, showing that the progressive decomposition of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite loaded on the surface of PC gradually exposes the ‘buried’ coal matrix of C@NNi with the increased temperatures. It is noteworthy that the bright nanoparticulate forms can be seen from the corresponding backscattered SEM images of the samples (Fig. S3b,d,f), indicating the successful incorporation of nickel into the coal matrices [22,33]. At the relatively low temperature of 600 ºC, a considerable amount of the undecomposed 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite exists at the surface of coal matrix, resulting in the encapsulation of numerous nickel atoms within CNNi-600 (Fig. S3b). As mentioned above, the pore structure of the coal matrix of CNNi-700 can tolerate the high-temperature condition. Thus, a relatively high concentration of particulate matter of Ni is still embedded within the coal matrix of CNNi-700 (Fig. S3d) by the anchoring effect of micropores, even though the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite has decomposed largely at such a high temperature. However, the shrinkage of the pore structure along with the disappearance of large quantities of micropores leads to a significant decrease in the metal loading at the excessively high temperature of 800 °C (Fig. S3f). Consequently, 700 °C is the most suitable temperature for exposing plentiful pores of the coal matrix while retaining sufficient nickel. By comparison with CNNi-700, the coal-free C-N-Ni-700 exhibits both an increased degree of agglomeration and an uneven dispersion of nanoparticulate nickel (Fig. S3g,h), demonstrating the significant role of the robust coal matrix in both protecting metal active centres against excessive agglomeration and controlling the size and dispersity of Ni nanoparticles.

The TEM measurements can also display the distribution of Ni anchored in the coal matrix. As exhibited in Fig. 2(a) and (c), the degree of agglomeration of Ni for CNNi-700 is indeed lower than for C-N-Ni-700 according to the observed metal particle sizes, consistent with the SEM measurements. Though part of nickel atoms of CNNi-700 agglomerate into nanoparticles, the elemental mapping by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy, depicted in Fig. 2(e)–(h), shows uniformly distributed nickel within the coal matrix of CNNi-700, indicating the anchoring and confinement effects of the micropore structure of coal matrix enable most of nickel to be distributed fairly uniformly [34]. In Fig. 2(b), the interlayer distance of lattice fringes of a nanoparticulate nickel is 0.21 nm, which can be ascribed to the Ni (111) crystallographic plane [19]. Evidently, the carbon domains around the Ni nanoparticle of CNNi-700 maintain the amorphous structure, similar to PC without being doped with Ni (Fig. S4), indicating many defects that may originate from abundant micropores of coal matrix do exist surrounding the metal active centres and therefore favour the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. By contrast, the carbon domains that are adjacent to the nanoparticulate nickel of coal-free C-N-Ni-700 are readily transformed into an ordered graphitized structure, identified by the graphitic lattice spacing of 0.35 nm (Fig. 2d) [35,36]. The distinctive contrast between the two types of carbon supports demonstrates the robust architecture of coal matrix is not easily affected by the metal and able to supply ample reaction sites.

As revealed in Fig. 3(a), the two diffraction peaks centred at about 42.6º and 25.9º correspond to the (100) and (002) planes of the graphite structure (JCPDS No. 41-1487), respectively [37]. Meanwhile, the three peaks located at 76.5º, 51.8º and 44.5º are assigned to the (220), (200) and (111) planes of nickel (JCPDS No. 87-0712), respectively [21]. It is worth mentioning that the position of the diffraction peak of graphitic carbon (100) crystal plane is in close proximity to that of Ni (111) crystal plane, causing partial overlap of the two peaks. Additionally, CNNi-600 has an extra diffraction peak located at 47.5º, which may originate from a Ni-containing intermediate produced during the pyrolysis of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite (Fig. S5). Furthermore, the intensities of diffraction peaks of metallic Ni as well as graphitic carbon of CNNi-700 remain weak without distinct change, much lower than for C-N-Ni-700, which strongly evidences that the coal matrix with the robust framework can effectively suppress the agglomeration of nickel. When the temperature rises to 800 °C, the spatial confinement effect of pore structure of coal matrix can readily obstruct the agglomeration of nickel, whereas the carbon microcrystals within the carbon support tend to agglomerate under the action of the excessively high temperature, leading to the transformation of amorphous carbon into ordered graphitized carbon [38]. Fig. 3(b) shows the Raman spectra, in which all the samples exhibit the two characteristic peaks located at 1590 cm–1 (G band) and 1350 cm–1 (D band) [39,40]. Generally, the G band is attributed to the orderly hexagonal graphitic carbon, while the D band is evolved from the structural defects in the carbon matrix [41]. The ratio of the intensity of the D band to that of the G band, referred to as I D /I G, is 1.08 for CNNi-700, larger than for CNNi-600 (1.02), which should be ascribed to the exposure of a large quantity of micropores in the coal matrix [26,32]. For CNNi-800, microcrystalline carbon agglomerates under the influence of high temperature, resulting in the reduction of micropores along with the growth of graphitized structure, and hence CNNi-800 has the lower intensity ratio (I D /I G = 0.77) than CNNi-700. Moreover, metal nanoparticles in C-N-Ni-700 favours the graphitization of the surrounding carbon in the calcination step, which gives rise to a reduced number of defect sites (I D /I G = 0.82) compared with CNNi-700 and is therefore consistent with the TEM observations, so the addition of the robust and porous coal matrix enables CNNi-700 to contain abundant active sites involving the CO2RR.

The XPS measurements have been taken to research into the chemical compositions and elemental states of the as-obtained electrocatalysts. The survey spectra ( Fig. 4a) show that CNNi-600, CNNi-700, CNNi-800 and C-N-Ni-700 all own the carbon, oxygen, nitrogen and nickel elements, indicating the successful co-doping of N and Ni into the coal matrix [42]. With the elevation of temperature, the gradual decomposition of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite loaded on the coal support leads to the lower N level (Table S2). As exhibited in Fig. 4(b,d,e,f) the high-resolution Ni 2p3/2 spectra of all the samples can be split into the two sub-peaks at 853.1 and 855.2 eV, corresponding to Ni0 and Ni+, respectively [43]. The ratio of Ni0 to Ni+ for CNNi-600 is close to 1 (Fig. 4b), indicating that half of Ni is fixed within the coal matrix in the form of Ni-N bonding while the other half is in the form of Ni0 [19]. After the almost complete decomposition of the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite at 700 °C, the Ni-N component anchored in the micropores of coal matrix becomes dominant (Fig. 4d). At 800 °C, the disappearance of the Ni0 peak for CNNi-800 (Fig. 4e) can be credited to the micropore shrinkage by which the Ni0 component is either leached from the coal matrix or buried deeply within the matrix. This can also be identified by the ICP-MS measurements (Table S3). As the temperature increases to 800 °C, the Ni content in the surface layer of the sample decreases by 62.7% based on the XPS data, whereas the ICP-MS results show that the total Ni content is only reduced by 28.7%, which evidently demonstrates that part of the Ni0 component in the surface layer that can be detected by the XPS technique is deeply encapsulated within the coal matrix by the action of micropore shrinkage. Additionally, the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectra for CNNi-600, CNNi-700, CNNi-800 and C-N-Ni-700 can be each split into the two peaks positioned at 401 and 399 eV, ascribed to graphitic and pyridinic nitrogen, respectively (Fig. 4c,g,h,i) [44,45]. A high proportion of pyridinic nitrogen contributes to the formation of catalytically active Ni-N species, which in turn can anchor adequate nickel in the pore structure of the coal matrix [46]. Interestingly, both contents and chemical states of Ni and N for CNNi-700 are similar to those for C-N-Ni-700, indicating their almost identical surface chemical compositions (Table S2). Thus, the existence of coal matrix merely tailors the sample morphology without changing the surface components, which helps to evaluate the impact of matrix engineering on the electrocatalytic activity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Boosting electrocatalytic performance: roles of coal matrix
ce:section.ce:para: We first study the electrocatalytic CO2RR activities of the as-obtained samples in a three-electrode system. All the reported potentials herein are based on the RHE scale. Fig. 5(a) exhibits the LSV curves of CNNi-700 measured in the saturated atmosphere of N2 or CO2. When the potential sweeps to negative potentials of less than −0.5V, the reduction current of CNNi-700 in the CO2-saturated electrolyte is obviously deviated from that in the N2 atmosphere, indicating its promising electrocatalytic activity concerning the CO2RR [47]. In addition, CNNi-700 still maintains relatively high catalytic performance in the CO2 atmosphere at the potentials of below −1 V, which suggests that the electrocatalyst can withstand larger reduction potentials [48]. As exhibited in Fig. S6, the largest current density produced by CNNi-700 among all the samples between –1.25 and −0.5 V manifests the advantages of robust coal matrix that provides both protection and adequate active sites for the efficiently electrocatalytic CO2RR.

The chronoamperometric method is further employed to evaluate the catalytic selectivity of the samples at various potentials. CO and H2 are detected as the major reduction products (the total FEs close to 100%) without any liquid-phase products. Fig. 5(b) and S7 show the FE values of CO (FECO) and H2 (FEH2) as a function of applied potentials, respectively. It is worth noting that CNNi-700 exhibits the great selectivity to CO, identified by its high FECO (above 90%) from –0.6 to −1.1 V. Particularly, CNNi-700 delivers the largest FECO of 98% at the relatively low potential of −0.8 V, demonstrating the excellent electrochemical performance of Ni-N active centres anchored in the micropores of coal matrix [19,46]. In spite of the largest amount of nickel atoms for CNNi-600 among the samples (Table S2), almost half of them exist in the form of Ni0, which tend to be more biased towards the HER and thus result in its low selectivity to CO (the largest FECO of 73% at −0.9 V) [33]. In addition, CNNi-800 also presents the lower FECO than CNNi-700. The pore shrinkage produced by the excessively high temperature not only causes the disappearance of plentiful micropores and the decrease in the number of active centres involving the CO2RR but also leads to the graphitization of carbon skeletons and therefore generates numerous reaction sites biased towards H2 production. Similar to other carbon-nitrogen-metal catalysts prepared by the calcination of organic ligands and metal-salt precursors, C-N-Ni-700 derived from the 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite shows an acceptable FECO of 84% at −0.8 V. However, limited by its easily graphitized carbon framework and unevenly dispersed active sites, C-N-Ni-700 cannot effectively suppress the HER like CNNi-700.

Fig. 5(c) summarizes the partial current densities for CO (j CO) at the corresponding applied potentials. The j CO values of CNNi-700 increase rapidly with the negative shift in potentials. As predicted, the spatial confinement growth effect of coal matrix can anchor plenty of Ni atoms into the micropores in the form of Ni-N bonding. Further, the abundant micropores favour the absorption of numerous CO2 molecules as the substrate for the Ni-N catalytic sites, thereby resulting in the efficiently electrocatalytic CO2RR at the electrode surface. Nevertheless, the j CO values decrease after attaining the maximum value of 57 mA cm–2 at −1.1 V because the CO2 diffusion from the bulk electrolyte to the electrolyte/electrode interface becomes limited by the mass transport. Additionally, great quantities of electrons are absorbed by hydrogen ions at the electrode surface, resulting in the reduction of CO2-to-CO conversion rate at the relatively negative potentials (< −1.1 V) [49]. Moreover, CNNi-700 has the higher current densities than C-N-Ni-700 at each of the same potentials, attributed to the highly efficient electron/substrate interaction over the active sites based on the robust coal matrix of CNNi-700. More specifically, the unique micropore structure of coal matrix favours the uniform distribution of Ni-N active sites, thus enhancing the utilization of nickel. Furthermore, electrons are able to transport rapidly in the dense skeleton structure of coal matrix and can be absorbed by CO2 molecules under the efficiently catalytic action of Ni-N catalytic centres. The turnover frequency (TOF) value of CNNi-700 is larger than that of C-N-Ni-700 at the relatively negative potentials (Fig. S8), demonstrating that the activity of Ni-N in the micropores of coal matrix is higher than in the mesopores of C-N-Ni-700 (Smes/SBET = 0.93). On the other hand, though CNNi-800 has the lower current density than CNNi-600 owning to the low Ni content of the former, CNNi-800 has the greater TOF value than CNNi-600 from –0.7 to −1.2 V. Ni atoms located in the surface layer of CNNi-800 are anchored in the micropores in the form of Ni-N, whereas part of Ni atoms in CNNi-600 are located in the undecomposed 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite, therefore showing that the micropores of coal matrix can significantly improve the catalytic performance of Ni-N active sites. Consequently, the porous and robust coal matrix increases the catalyst utilization, accelerates the electron transport and enriches the reaction substrate, thereby intensifying the electron/substrate interaction over the active sites and finally achieving efficient electrocatalysis of CO2 to CO.

Moreover, the ECSA values have been measured to further interpret the role of coal matrix in electrocatalytic performance enhancement of active sites. C dl is employed as a reference of the ECSA in view of the positive linear relationship [50]. CNNi-700 contains the much greater ECSA than its counterparts (Fig. 5d), which suggests that it possesses the largest quantity of active sites. Considering the similar Ni contents located in the surface layers of CNNi-700 and C-N-Ni-700, the larger ECSA of CNNi-700 reveals that the micropore structure of coal matrix improves the dispersion of nickel, hence boosting the number of catalytic sites for the CO2RR. More undecomposed 2-MeIM/Ni2+ composite exists in the pore structure of coal matrix of CNNi-600 compared with CNNi-700, leading to the smaller ECSA of the former. As for CNNi-800, small quantities of micropores along with the low Ni content cause the tiny ECSA.

As shown in Fig. 6(a), the charge-transfer resistance (R CT) of CNNi-700 (1.2 ohms) is much smaller than for C-N-Ni-700 (4.2 ohms), demonstrating the outstanding electron-transfer kinetics of the coal matrix [51]. The electronic conductivity of CNNi-600 is lower than that of CNNi-700 due to the existence of many organic ligands in the surface layer of the former, which results in its relatively large R CT (3.3 ohms). The degree of graphitization for CNNi-800 is the highest (I D /I G = 0.77) among the samples (Fig. 3b), which favours the fast electron transport. However, the Ni content of CNNi-800 largely decreases, finally leading to the larger R CT (3.1 ohms). Furthermore, the overpotential (η) against the log of j CO is plotted in Fig. 6(b), and the Tafel slope values of CNNi-600, CNNi-700, CNNi-800 and C-N-Ni-700 are calculated to be 142, 105, 151 and 120 mV dec–1, respectively. The smallest Tafel slope of CNNi-700 indicates its strongest electron/substrate interaction of active sites within the coal matrix for the efficient formation of CO through the CO2RR, which originates from its abundant micropores, uniformly distributed nickel, smallest R CT and highest CO2 adsorption capacity [32,44]. Furthermore, the Tafel slope values of CNNi-700 and C-N-Ni-700 approach the theoretical value of 118 mV dec–1, predicting the process in which a carbon dioxide molecule gains the first electron to generate CO2 •– is the rate-limiting step [32]. To demonstrate this more clearly, the in situ ATR-SEIRAS experiments have been performed to probe the reaction mechanism involving the coal-matrix and coal-free catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6(c) and (d), the spectra of both CNNi-700 and C-N-Ni-700 exhibit the characteristic peaks of the key intermediate *COOH at approximately 1225 cm–1 [52]. Clearly, CNNi-700 exhibits the higher *COOH peak intensity than C-N-Ni-700 at the same electrolysis time, indicating the relatively higher catalytic rate for the former. In addition, the peaks located in the higher-frequency range at around 1930 cm–1 are assigned to CO bound to the Ni-N active sites [53]. According to the Tafel and in situ ATR-SEIRAS analyses, the reaction steps in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 for CNNi-700 and C-N-Ni-700 are identical:
CO2 + * + e– → CO2 •– *
CO2 •– * + H+ → *COOH*
*COOH* + H+ + e– → CO* + H2O
CO* → CO + *
where * is the adsorption site [32]. As a consequence, it can be summarized that the presence of coal matrix does not change the reaction steps but accelerate the catalytic rate.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Industrial potential: coal matrix in a flow cell
ce:section.ce:para: In order to address the mass transport limitation of carbon dioxide in the H-shaped cell and evaluate whether the coal-containing catalysts can withstand high currents, we have used a custom-made flow cell (Fig. S9) to investigate the electrochemical activity of CNNi-700 and C-N-Ni-700. As viewed in Fig. 7(a), CO2 molecules can pass through the gas diffusion layer (GDL) in the form of gas directly to the catalyst surface in contact with the flowing electrolyte, which can increase largely the substrate concentration surrounding active sites. In addition, the product CO can also diffuse rapidly through the GDL due to its low solubility in the aqueous solution [54]. Fig. 7(b) exhibits the j CO and FECO at the corresponding applied potentials. Evidently, CNNi-700 can retain the high selectivity towards CO with the greatly increased current density, and it yields the largest FECO of 97% and the industrial j CO of 223 mA cm–2 at −0.93 V (after the iR correction), indicating its high potentiality towards commercial application. It is worth mentioning that CNNi-700 shows the outstanding electrochemical performance, superior to recently reported electrocatalysts (Table S4). Furthermore, the stability of the as-obtained electrocatalyst is also crucial for the advancement of CO2RR systems. Thus, the long-term chronoamperometric experiments have been performed at a potential of −0.93 V. The current density produced by CNNi-700 remains stable after the 120-hour electrolysis (Fig. 7c); meanwhile, the FECO can maintain higher than 90% throughout the experiments, demonstrating its excellent durability at such a high electrolytic current. The slight increase in the current density (e.g. from the 90th to 100th h) can be ascribed to the surface tension of water within micropore domains, which prevents Ni in the depth of pores from contacting the electrolyte. As the electrolysis goes, the electrolyte gradually penetrates deeper in the coal matrix, which makes more nickel atoms participate in the CO2RR, thus increasing the current density. Overall, the current density by CNNi-700 proves to be steady in the long-term measurement, albeit with slightly oscillating signals due to random perturbation. In addition, the yield of CO can be maintained at 5722 mmol gcat –1 h–1. On the contrary, both the total current density and the FECO of C-N-Ni-700 decrease obviously with the prolonged electrolysis (Fig. S10), indicating its relatively poor stability. These results have disclosed that the robust coal matrix can not only effectively enhance the electron/substrate interaction and boost the catalytic rate but also protect the active sites with its robust architecture and therefore strengthen the catalyst durability.

We can now summarize the new knowledge we have gained from this investigation about how the robust coal matrix intensifies the electron/substrate interaction of Ni-N active sites. First, the abundant micropore structure of the coal matrix can favour the effective immobilization and uniform distribution of nickel within the coal matrix and enhance the catalyst utilization. Second, the surface pore structure and the internal dense framework of coal matrix not only boost the CO2 adsorption capacity and enrich the reaction substrate but also increase the electronic conductivity, thereby intensifying the electron/substrate interaction over the Ni-N active sites. The coal-matrix electrocatalyst CNNi-700 yields a high FECO of 97% as well as an industrial j CO of 223 mA cm–2 in the flow cell. Third, with the support and protection of the robust coal matrix, the electrochemical performance of CNNi-700 remains steady after the long-term electrolysis, demonstrating its outstanding durability. On the other hand, the importance of Ni-N active sites must not be neglected, which can be rationalized by noting that both CNNi-600 and CNNi-800 exhibit the inferior electrocatalytic CO2RR performance to CNNi-700 due to the meagre amounts of Ni-N active sites for the former two, though they all have the coal matrices. Consequently, the two major aspects, catalyst support and active site, should be considered together in terms of the electrocatalytic performance enhancement, which can be realized by the coal matrix. In this sense, our study not only describes a new strategy for synthesizing efficient coal-based electrocatalysts to produce CO through the CO2 electroreduction but also shed light on utilizing cost-effective coals as catalyst supports to intensify the actions of supports towards catalysts and hence optimize electrochemical performance involving related fields of energy conversion and storage.
